title: Add option to disable writing headers
body:
This option prevents metrics from being written in the corresponding
header of the response.

This is useful to collect the metrics all the time but have a setting to
actually write it in the answer. For instance, this is desirable for
https://github.com/miniflux/miniflux/pull/806/

title: Add Server-Timing header to unread page
body:
To be used as a basis to discuss #722. Current metrics may not be the
most interesting ones.

This is not deactivable at the moment, the header is:
```
server-timing: prep;dur=30.548655,sql_unread;dur=8.762088,sql_entries;dur=16.670605,render;dur=566.738683
```
*Do we want this feature to be configurable?*

The construction advised by the library
```
defer timing.NewMetric(name).Start().Stop()
```
does not work, the metric has a duration of 0s. I suspect this is due to
the request being finalized too early for the header to be added. Some
more granular metrics as added in this patch may be more relevant anyway.

Example result in browser:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7347374/93971171-76835a00-fd67-11ea-8a04-f93d5086d3b8.png)

title: Add fish shell completions
body: Generate fish shell completions at build time. Empower fish users with completions. Completions are copied in the [recommended directory](https://fishshell.com/docs/current/#where-to-put-completions). Describe **what** this PR changes. **Why** this is wanted. And, if needed, **how** it does it. Git checklist: * [X] Describe the change in **`CHANGELOG.md`** under the `[Unreleased]` header. * [X] Check that commits follow the [Mullvad coding guidelines](https://github.com/mullvad/coding-guidelines) --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/mullvad/mullvadvpn-app/1860)

title: Firefox dev tools support server timing
body: [Since version 71](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Server-Timing). The bug linked to is also closed.

title: Add shortcut to trigger webrtc
body: I find having a shortcut really handy.

title: go build error with go 1.13
body:
I had troubles building gopass with go 1.13. For instance, with an empty GOPATH, doing a `go get github.com/gopasspw/gopass` works. But with `go build` in `$GOPATH/src/github.com/gopasspw/gopass/`, I get
```
go: github.com/mgechev/revive@v0.0.0-20190726005920-de49a7b6832f requires
	github.com/mgechev/dots@v0.0.0-20190603122614-18fa4c4b71cc: invalid pseudo-version: does not match version-control timestamp (2018-12-28T16:47:30Z)
```

This may be related to [stricter module validation](https://tip.golang.org/doc/go1.13#version-validation) (“The go command now verifies the mapping between pseudo-versions and version-control metadata”) in go 1.13.
So I just updated revive to its current master.

I ran `make test` and `make test-integration` (both successfully). However, `make codequality` returns:
```
     STATICCHECK /usr/lib/go/src/unicode/utf8/utf8.go:28:8: expected ';', found b00000000 (and 10 more errors)
couldn't load packages due to errors: golang.org/x/net/http/httpproxy, golang.org/x/crypto/nacl/secretbox, text/template and 65 more
make: *** [Makefile:173: codequality] Error 1
```

title: Describe 9.9.9.10 more accurately
body: There are now precise details about the “insecure” service at [the Quad9 FAQ](https://web.archive.org/web/20190308113416/https://quad9.net/faq/#Is_there_a_service_that_Quad9_offers_that_does_not_have_the_blocklist_or_other_security). I think this new comment is more accurate.

title: Make rofi prompt explicit
body:
As a new user, I find it hard to know what will be done with a generic
"Select group" prompt. I almost never know whether I will focus another
group or move current windows to another group.

title: Add references to RFCs defining good documentation practices
body:
In these RFCs, great details and example are given about the right way to do
documentation. I’m not sure if this is worth being detailed on
cheats.rs, but a link is a way as good as another to find these
documents.

In particular, these RFC are way more detailed than the Reference book.

See Rust-lang [Contributing.md][RContrib] for a proof that RFC1574 is used for std.

[RContrib]: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#writing-documentation

title: Add cargo aliases
body:
Cargo aliases are not that easy to find, I think it’s handy to have it here.

This list comes from https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/6218/

title: Add https to markdown links
body: Without this, you get a Github 404.

title: Configurable threshold in temperature block
body:
It’s pretty handy to adapt the threshold from one state to another to
your own hardware.

This is also a feature mentioned as missing in `blocks.md`.

title: Fix dead link to USB keycodes doc
body:
Link was dead and the fresher version I could find on usb.org (http://www.usb.org/developers/hidpage/Hut1_12v2.pdf) is still older than this one.

Thus, WaybackMachine seems the best option.

title: Refresh & improve leader documentation page
body:
- `register_code`/`unregister_code` are not the recommended way to do macro.
- Provide some details I wish I had found when first used the leader
  functionality.

Did not check optional dependencies, got problems with ojs-base and gave up.

They now appear to be lists.

title: Add contextual help with the preview server
body:
This saves the user from browsing the documentation (https://zoggy.github.io/stog/server.html) to find why opening the browser on the listening address is not working.

However, the style of the code may be improved, since we pass the same argument twice.

It may be interesting to add the same sort of thing for the editor.

title: Add new preversion of OcLaunch
body: New preversion of OcLaunch

title: Correct lastmod date in sitemap
body:
Date should be in [W3C Datetime format](http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime), according to http://www.sitemaps.org/protocol.html.

Current format of date is not recognised by Google.

_I didn't build stog with this, but it should work. I tested the format with `date` command and the library._

title: Add alternative software to the Readme
body: Very similar program, would be interesting too.

title: Add OcLaunch project
body: OcLaunch adopted these [rules](http://oclaunch.tuxfamily.org/rules)

title: It's better to say 'bogue' in French
body: It's recommended to use 'bogue' instead of 'bug' in French. See http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/jopdf/common/jo_pdf.jsp?numJO=0&dateJO=19840219&pageDebut=51740&pageFin=&pageCourante=51741 and https://fr.wiktionary.org/wiki/bogue#fr-nom-4

title: For a bug, 'rapporter' seems more correct than 'reporter'
body:
You may be interested these articles: https://fr.wiktionary.org/wiki/rapporter and https://fr.wiktionary.org/wiki/reporter.

In one word, 'reporter' could translated by 'to postpone' while 'rapporter' would be 'to report'.

Another interesting page: http://www.wordreference.com/enfr/report

title: Update homepage code sample
body: Update date of the transaction, to show that project is active/modern/...

body: See zoggy/stog#16

title: Colorized code is more user friendly
Json api
body:
It would be great to be able to write script using the number of tests passed, time spent and so on.

I started to add a json api, providing the results of the tests. But I can't call this from the command line.
I would like to do

``` sh
alcotest --api
```

to get the json output, usable by a computer, like this:

``` json
{"s":2,"f":5,"t":0.5}
```

How would I get this?

Thanks
